title: 106_hr1744
content: The Act is titled the "National Institute of Standards and Technology Authorization Act of 1999" and authorizes appropriations for scientific and technical research and services. The National Institute of Standards and Technology Authorization Act of 1999 authorizes appropriations for laboratory activities of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, including funding for Electronics, Manufacturing, Chemical Science, Physics, Material Science, Building and Fire Research, and Computer Science. The National Institute of Standards and Technology Authorization Act of 1999 authorizes appropriations for various programs including Technical Assistance, Research Support, Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Program, and Construction and Maintenance funding for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. The National Institute of Standards and Technology Authorization Act of 1999 authorizes $31,800,000 for construction in fiscal year 2001. Funds cannot be used without the Secretary of Commerce certifying to the relevant committees that it aligns with the institute's facilities plan. Authorization of appropriations for the Office of the Under Secretary for Technology includes $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2001. Additionally, there is authorization of appropriations for Industrial Technology Services. Authorization of appropriations for Industrial Technology Services activities of the National Institute of Standards and Technology includes $297,500,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $256,700,000 for fiscal year 2001, with allocations for the Advanced Technology Program and Manufacturing Extension Partnerships program. Authorization of appropriations for Industrial Technology Services activities of the National Institute of Standards and Technology includes $106,800,000 for the Manufacturing Extension Partnerships program under sections 25 and 26 of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the National Technical Information Service and amendments to the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act. Amendments to the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act include changes related to joint venture costs and grant recipient conditions. The amendments to the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act involve providing financial assistance for projects that would not be pursued in a timely manner without federal assistance. The Secretary may vest title to tangible personal property in recipients if it furthers the objectives of the Institute. The National Institute of Standards and Technology Act is amended to allow for financial assistance to joint ventures, with the amendment effective for future proposals after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. Technical amendments include changes to research fellowships and outdated specifications related to the metric system. SEC. 8. Eligibility for awards is also addressed. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will exclude individuals from grant agreements if they received non-competitive federal funds after fiscal year 1999, except for specific cases. This exclusion lasts for 5 years. There is an exception for funds received based on membership in a specified class. The term "grant agreement" refers to a legal instrument transferring value for a public purpose, excluding property or services for direct government benefit. It does not include cooperative agreements or cooperative research and development agreements.
